ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Days since baseline
Assessment Point
Notes: D=MTA baseline assessment; 14=MTA 14 month assessment; E=MTA early termination assessment; B = MTA Pre-Baseline Screening Assessment (579/579); 09 = MTA 9 Month Assessment (530/530); 24=MTA 24 month assessment; LB=LNCG baseline assessment; 36=MTA and LNCG 3 year assessment; 72=MTA and LNCG 6 year assessment; 96=MTA and LNCG 8 year assessment; 03 = MTA 3 Month Assessment (438/687);120=MTA and LNCG 10 year assessment; 7= 7th Grade Assessment (221/276); 144 = MTA & LNCG 12 Month Assessment (578/578); 168 = MTA & LNCG 14 Month Assessment (585/585); 192 = MTA & LNCG 16 Month Assessment (505/505); C = MTA Pre-Baseline Screening Assessment (78/78)

ElementDescription: Active status
Notes: 0=Inactive-Data collected after the 14 month treatment phase/after early termination from treatment phase/prior to treatment phase; 1=Active-Data collected during the 14 month treatment phase while subject received originally assigned treatment regardless of degree of compliance; 2=Active-This is the last active assessment for subjects who were about to violate treatment arm by receiving alternate treatment; 3=Active-This is the last active assessment for subjects who were about to leave the study by moving away;4=Yes, Active; 5=No, Not Active

ElementDescription: Site
Notes: Study Site

ElementDescription: Subject type
Notes: 1=MTA randomized trial subject; 2=Local normative comparison group (LNCG) subject

ElementDescription: What type of alcoholic beverage do you consume most often when you do drink?
Notes: 0=Beer; 1=Wine; 2=Mixed drinks; 3=Straight drinks; 4=Other; 5=Lifelong alcohol abstainer; 6=Current alcohol abstainer

ElementDescription: On the average, how often do you consume alcoholic beverages of any kind?
Notes: 0=Once a month or less; 1=2 or 3 times a month; 2=Once a week; 3=Twice a week; 4=3 or 4 times a week; 5=5 or 6 times a week; 6=7 or 8 times a week; 7=9-13 times a week; 8=14-20 times a week; 9=21 or more times a week

ElementDescription: On the average, how many drinks do you have each time or on each occasion when you do consume alcoholic beverages?
Notes: 0=less than one whole drink; 7=7-9 drinks; 8=10-12 drinks; 9=More than 12 drinks

ElementDescription: About how long have you been either abstaining or drinking at your present rate?
Notes: 0=3 months or less; 1=3-6 months; 2=6-12 months; 3=1-2 years; 4=2-3 years; 5=3-4 years; 6=4-5 years; 7=5-8 years; 8=8-10 years; 9=more than 10 years

ElementDescription: What was your rate of alcohol consumption before you established your current level?
Notes: 0=I did not drink at all then; 1=I used to drink much less; 2=I used to drink somewhat less; 3=I used to drink somewhat more; 4=I used to drink much more

ElementDescription: On the average, how often do you get at least somewhat high or somewhat intoxicated from drinking alcoholic beverages?
Notes: 0=less than once a month; 1=once a month; 2=twice a month; 3=3 times a month; 4=once a week; 5=2 times a week; 6=3 times a week; 7=4 times a week; 8=5-7 times a week; 9=more than 7 times a week

ElementDescription: When you do get somewhat high or somewhat intoxicated, how many drinks does it usually take?
Notes: 0=I have never felt somewhat high or intoxicated; 1=1 or fewer drinks; 2=2 drinks; 3=3 drinks; 4=4 drinks; 5=5 drinks; 6=6 drinks; 7=7-9 drinks; 8=10-12 drinks; 9=more than 12 drinks

ElementDescription: On the average, how often do you get drunk?
Notes: 0=less than once a month; 1=once a month; 2=twice a month; 3=3 times a month; 4=once a week; 5=2 times a week; 6=3 times a week; 7=4 times a week; 8=5-7 times a week; 9=more than 7 times a week

ElementDescription: When you do get drunk, how many drinks does it usually take?
Notes: 0=I have never been drunk; 1=1 or fewer drinks; 2=2 drinks; 3=3 drinks; 4=4 drinks; 5=5 drinks; 6=6 drinks; 7=7-9 drinks; 8=10-12 drinks; 9=more than 12 drinks

ElementDescription: In comparison to the average person of your same age, sex, and body weight, how well would you say you hold your liquor?
Notes: 0=Much less; 1=Somewhat less; 2=About the same; 3=Somewhat more; 4=Much more; 5=Alcohol abstainer

ElementDescription: How often in the past 12 months have your children seen you drinking alcoholic beverages or seen you soon enough after drinking that you still were affected by alcohol in your system?
Notes: 0=Never; 1=Once or twice; 2=2-6 times; 3=6-12 times; 4=more than 12 times

ElementDescription: Drinking is bad for your health
Notes: 1=Very important reason; 2=Somewhat important reason; 3=Not an important reason; 4=Not a reason

ElementDescription: It costs too much when you need money for other things
Notes: 1=Very important reason; 2=Somewhat important reason; 3=Not an important reason; 4=Not a reason

ElementDescription: Your family or friends get upset when you drink
Notes: 1=Very important reason; 2=Somewhat important reason; 3=Not an important reason; 4=Not a reason

ElementDescription: It may interfere with your job or work
Notes: 1=Very important reason; 2=Somewhat important reason; 3=Not an important reason; 4=Not a reason

ElementDescription: It goes against your religion
Notes: 1=Very important reason; 2=Somewhat important reason; 3=Not an important reason; 4=Not a reason

ElementDescription: You are afraid of becoming an alcoholic
Notes: 1=Very important reason; 2=Somewhat important reason; 3=Not an important reason; 4=Not a reason

ElementDescription: Drinking too often makes you do things you are sorry for later on
Notes: 1=Very important reason; 2=Somewhat important reason; 3=Not an important reason; 4=Not a reason

ElementDescription: Drinking can make you feel sick
Notes: 1=Very important reason; 2=Somewhat important reason; 3=Not an important reason; 4=Not a reason

ElementDescription: Drinking can get you into trouble with the police or authorities
Notes: 1=Very important reason; 2=Somewhat important reason; 3=Not an important reason; 4=Not a reason

ElementDescription: Drinking leads to losing control over your life
Notes: 1=Very important reason; 2=Somewhat important reason; 3=Not an important reason; 4=Not a reason

ElementDescription: Number of Drinks Per Week
Notes: This is computed by multiplying number of drinking occasions per week (DRHX2) by number of drinks per drinking occasion (DRHX3)

ElementDescription: In the past 30 days, on how many days did you drink: at a bar, pub, or nightclub?
Notes: Number of Days; 1= 1 Day; 30= 30 days
